Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Control Design for Dynamical Network Flows with Applications to Transportation

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
As our society is becoming more dependent on critical infrastructure networks such as transportation, communication, water, power, and gas, their efficient and resilient operation is becoming ever more important. Hence, one of the engineering grand challenges identified by the National Academy of Engineering is to restore and improve urban infrastructure systems. However, as recent evaluations by the American Society of Civil Engineers show, the state of our infrastructure systems continues to be substandard, and will likely remain so without massive investments. With significant growth in demand projected, a future infrastructure system that maintains the status quo will not function even at today's current, often inadequate, levels. It is increasingly being realized that leveraging sensing, actuation, and information technologies can achieve substantial improvements in the performance of these systems. These cyber technologies have the potential to endow our infrastructure networks with the capability to dynamically respond to changes in demand, supply, and even physical properties under disruptions. The existing approaches to control of infrastructure networks, however, are inadequate to realize the potential of this capability. This is because they are either heuristic with no formal performance guarantees; or they adopt static abstractions, and hence are useful only for long term planning; or the dynamical frameworks are used only for simulation and analysis purposes with little or no consideration for control design. The project will develop an integrated research and education program on rigorous control design for intelligent infrastructure networks, with a special emphasis on transportation. Collaborations with local transportation and planning agencies will facilitate rapid transition from research to practice. The outreach activities include development of an interactive traffic simulator, which would also serve as an experiment test bed to model dynamic driver behavior; and interactive network interdiction games to demonstrate the concepts of cascading failures and network robustness to general public. The education activities include development of new courses on analysis, control and estimation of infrastructure networks. Research opportunities will be expanded for undergraduates to implement control algorithms on professional transportation software to generate case studies, which will be used for our interactions with transportation agencies. Existing programs at the University of Southern California will be utilized to integrate inclusive teaching practices into educational activities in order to address retention of women, underrepresented and minority students.

Network flow is a natural modeling paradigm for several infrastructure networks. The current state-of-the-art in theoretical network flow research primarily consists of algorithms for fast computation of maximum network flow capacity, or optimal flow distribution with respect to some performance metrics; and numerical analysis of dynamical network flows with cascade effects under fixed routing policies. The intellectual merits of the proposed research are: (i) a dynamical network flow framework that models coupling between dynamics of flow and jumps in network topology, e.g., due to cascading failures, as well as facilitates control design; (ii) new advancements in analysis for nonlinear dynamical systems using differential analysis and contraction principles, and applying them for analysis and control synthesis under proposed dynamical network flow; (iii) a computational framework for quantifying margins of resilience in terms of the disturbance generation process, network topology, and cascade dynamics; (iv) application of proposed tools to transportation through dynamic signal control, and inclusion of resilience metric in network design. The margin of resilience computations will identify canonical network flow concepts, besides the classical notion of cuts, as key indicators of network performance from efficiency and resilience perspective, under control and dynamical considerations. Beyond its immediate emphasis on dynamical network flows, the project aims to develop elements of robust control theory for networked dynamical systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the project was to develop control policies for dynamical network flow with applications to civil infrastructure systems such as transportation. The focus of methodologies was on robustness to disruptions, distributed control architecture, and customized computational tools for underlying nonconvex optimization and nonlinear optimal control problems.  

 

We characterized distributed routing policies with provable robustness properties. While it is natural to expect that distributed information leads to loss in robustness, we identified dynamical flow network scenarios where additional control action can compensate for lack of global information, and thus ensure maximum possible robustness. Essentially, the extra control action allows for implicit exchange through the dynamics to compensate for explicit information.

 

Other forms of distributed control were also shown to perform close to optimal for traffic networks. For example, distributed scheduling policies inspired by proportionally fair algorithms from communication networks were shown to give optimal throughput for averaged model of traffic flow dynamics. We also analytically characterized freeway traffic control setups (using ramp metering, variable speed limit control, and routing) in which distributed feedback control gives the same performance (e.g., in terms of travel time) as centralized control. Simulation studies over practical networks, such as in the Los Angeles area, suggest that this finding potentially holds much broadly than suggested by theoretical analysis. On the other hand, preliminary studies with natural gas networks suggests that distributed controllers may not necessarily be able to match the performance of centralized control for all civil infrastructure networks.

 

We posed and proposed solutions to the transmission capacity problem for power networks, i.e., computing maximum power that can be transmitted between two given nodes of the network, subject to thermal limits on the lines, using power electronic devices. The underlying problem is computationally challenging. At the core of our approach was the discovery of a quasi-concave relationship between transmission capacity and line properties which remains invariant across different resolutions of the network. We also tackled the problem of controlling a power network through load shedding over multiple rounds when the demand exceeds capacity. The key to our approach for solving this computationally challenging problem is a tractable decision tree representation of the control problem, using abstractions inspired by computational geometric concepts involving arrangement of hyperplanes.

 

The research results were published in IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control, IEEE Transactions on Control of Network Systems, Transportation Research Part B: Methodological, Annual Reviews of Control, Robotics, and Autonomous Systems, and Encyclopedia of Systems and Control.

 

Two PhD students and one postdoc, who were partially supported by this project, have gone on to pursue careers in industry. During the course of this project, the PI developed a new graduate course on Transportation Systems Analysis, and revamped an existing undergraduate course on Principles of Transportation Engineering and Economics, both at USC. The course projects in these courses are heavily inspired by the topics of this NSF project. Several undergraduate and Masters students from these courses did directed research with the PI, several of whom won scholarships from transportation agencies, and have gone on to pursue graduate studies in transportation.

 

The basic green split control algorithm for traffic signals, supported in part by this project, has been licensed, through USC, to Xtelligent, Inc., a startup cofounded by the PI.  Ongoing pilot tests of advanced traffic signal control system developed by the startup are suggesting 20%+ improvement in performance in comparison to the current state-of-the-art incumbent systems. This startup has won Harvard Business School Alumni New Venture Competition (regional), LA new mobility challenge, as well as SBIR awards from the Department of Energy.
